TopicTitle: Devnote Tuesdays: The "Let's Do the Time Warp Again" Edition

Articles.Content: @KerbMav: My plea meant no disrespect, joining Kerano (who included a nice pic illustrating the "correct method" of adding intakes and engines - sticking them on in arbitrary orders does not work well) and others, requesting improvements to the air flow logic similar to what HarvesteR is doing for the fuel flow to air-breathing engines. With respect to fuel, he wrote "...fuel line links... Quite a chore for something that would be expected to just work." I'm echoing that, thinking of the hours I spent playing with craft designs and reading the support forums, to understand how to work around high-altitude asymmetric engine flame-outs.

So what are the things you Ã¢â‚¬Å“alwaysÃ¢â‚¬Â forget about when designing a vessel?

CoM not aligned with CoT (bad symetry on some part?)

controling unit unaligned with coordinates (probe core turned upside down or something)

ladder is best friend of l

extraneous fuel duct of fuel tank (fuel pipe leading to part which cannot transfer fuel or fuel tank not accessible by any engine. this may even cover xenon tank without electric engine or monoprop on ship without any RCS ports)

starving engine (jet engine present but not air intakes, electric engine without xenon, RCS ports without monoprop tank)

first stage TWR to low (not to play on mechjebs/KER playground, just to tell whether the thing is able to take off at all)

crew hatch inaccessible (especially in those situations where partialy obscured hatch will shoot poor kerbal away)

LV-N in first stage (these are not exactly enviromentaly friendly, right?)

undirigable (no torque/control surfaces present)

undirigable II. (docking port present, but no RCS)

launch clamps not in first stage (I really dont know why clamps should not be placed in first stage automaticaly, always)

engine staged to fire before spearator attached to it (Nedelin Kerman can attest this is a bad stuff)

no downlink (if there is renewable science source but no antena)

RCS fuel tank on ship without RCS ports or vice versa

no juice

more juice (if there is xenon engine involved, number of solar arrays and batteries should exceed some arbitrary threshold. Nothing complicated, just to warn newbs that this thing is more hungry then what they are used to)

separatrons not separating (if separatrons are not in same stage as some decoupler, they are probably wrong)

ship without either pilot or SAS

Ã¢â‚¬Â¦and of course, check cookies in hitchhiker.

I'll second this. There is no real reason I can think of that you would want the backside of a docking port connected to either side of another docking port or decoupler and we get questions about this all the time. I presume this checklist is not going to interfere with launching so if someone is building something silly they could still do it.

Speaking about decouplers: When putting a 1.25m decoupler below a 0.625m engine, it can easily happen that you connect the engine's lower node with the lower node of the decoupler instead of its upper one (I'm not talking about having the decoupler upside-down). I think that should also be checked by the game. Let's be honest, that's rather a result from a GUI quirks than a real construction mistake of the user.

Other than that, I'm not such a big friend of too much checks for user's mistakes. At some point it starts feeling like the game playing itself instead of letting the user play (and learn from his mistakes).

Maybe this feature could come in the form of an unobtrusive button that changes color (green if everything okay, yellow for potential issues and red for probable issues), but only if you click it, it would show you a window with details. But you could still just press "Launch" without the game warning you. And if you did not pay attention to the button -- your problem.

Probably a bit late to the discussion, but I think that the STAGE_PRIORITY flow logic is a terrible choice for jet fuel. I would honestly rather have to set up fuel lines, than have to deal with the aftermath of rocket/jet engines having different fuel flow rules. If you have dedicated jet fuel tanks and rocket fuel tanks, all staged together like you would have on a typical actiongroup-controlled SSTO flight, how do you ensure that the rocket fuel tanks don't have fuel siphoned out of them by the jets? Taking into account the fact that actiongroups can't be used to enable/disable resource flow?

I'm confused as to why some people are up in arms about fuel draining from all tanks at the same rate.

Sure there are planes out there(IRL) with multiple tanks. But having your center of weight change on you in flight, isn't a good thing. It's a bad thing. It just makes more sense to keep the center of weight stationary.

Think of a plane like the Cessna 172. Very simple gravity fed fuel with a tank in each wing. They cross feed. So that they drain at the same rate. Would you want to have one drain, and then the other? It wouldn't make any sense. The plane would be heavy on one side. And could potentially lose control and flip over. Not a lot different from tanks along the longitudinal axis like most planes in KSP end up being. And then you typically end up with a tail heavy situation. As opposed to keeping everything balanced. It just makes more sense to have everything stay balanced.

I've flown 172's and i've flown planes where you have to manually set the tanks to either cross feed or select which is supplying fuel to the engine. I have never met a pilot who said that they would rather fly the plane where you have to manage your fuel.

So, if from a pilot's perspective it makes more sense. so why are people against it?

I long ago saw the light, and build most of my planes with a single fuel tank centered directly on the CoM. Problem solved. Do whatever you want to fuel flow, this will still work perfectly fine.

Although, after thinking about it for five seconds... all ye naysayers just need to put equal amounts of fuel forward and aft of the CoM, distributed into whatever labyrinthine arrangement of tanks turns you on. Problem solved.

Left/right side draining is a different thing. It's handled by symmetry in KSP, or more generally the tree structure of the fuel chain. And honestly, I see no problem with draining from all tanks at once. The issue is entirely unrelated.

STAGE_PRIORITY is the same resource use principle used in RCS and Xenon tanks. It will drain fuel from tanks not connected to the chain.

If there was a different fuel flow setting, i.e. "STAGE_FLOW" or something, which would treat all connected tanks as one and drained fuel from then at the same rate, that would be perfect.

The reason STAGE_PRIORITY is being used is because right now, surface-attached fuel tanks (such as wet wings will be) do not have fuel crossfeed, so you'd have to have fuel lines leading from them. As others have pointed out, this is already fixed by the CrossfeedEnabler mod, so beyond some twisted desire not to use a concept already used by a mod, I see no reason not to borrow the same solution.
